title: 103_hr2942
content: The "George Washington National Forest Mount Pleasant Scenic Area Act" aims to protect and preserve the scenic quality, water quality, natural characteristics, and water resources of the area. It also focuses on managing vegetation for wildlife habitat, developing old-growth forests, and providing recreational opportunities. The George Washington National Forest Mount Pleasant Scenic Area is established in Virginia, consisting of approximately 7580 acres. The Secretary will file a map and boundary description of the scenic area with the relevant committees. The Secretary of Agriculture will administer the George Washington National Forest Mount Pleasant Scenic Area in Virginia according to the laws and regulations applicable to the National Forest System. This Act takes precedence in case of conflicts with other laws and regulations. Within three years of this Act's enactment, the Secretary will develop a management plan for the scenic area, aligning with the Act's provisions. No new permanent roads will be built in the area, except for access to private lands. Vegetation management in the scenic area allows for necessary timber harvest for fire, insects, and diseases control, as well as for public safety and trail access. The Secretary may conduct vegetation manipulation for wildlife clearings and visual quality. Motorized travel is permitted on State Route 635 and Forest Development Road 51 with conditions imposed by the Secretary. No motorized travel is allowed in other areas of the scenic area. The scenic area prohibits motorized travel, except for administrative use and wildlife management projects. Wildfires will be suppressed, insect and disease outbreaks controlled, water quality maintained, and mining activities restricted.
